content.raw:
This is really cool and has a very powerful API! I played a bit with it and made a 3d plot plugin :smile: https://youtu.be/2OQc2Njjmcw 

The plugin is in branch [markers_3d_plot](#!/osrf/gazebo/branches/compare/markers_3d_plot%0Dmarkers#diff), but it's not very useful yet.

The plugin is using `SPHERE`, which at 100Hz, quickly overwhelms the render engine. I also tried:

* `LINE_LIST`, appending a point to the message at each iteration and using the same id, so it modifies the previous one. For some reason that was only drawing the beginning of the line and then it stopped. The message seemed to be properly growing though. I didn't investigate much further.

* `POINTS`, adding a new point each iteration, basically the same as for the spheres, but the points weren't showing up. I didn't investigate much more either.
content.html:
This is really cool and has a very powerful API! I played a bit with it and made a 3d plot plugin https://youtu.be/2OQc2Njjmcw

The plugin is in branch markers_3d_plot, but it's not very useful yet.

The plugin is using SPHERE, which at 100Hz, quickly overwhelms the render engine. I also tried:

  • LINE_LIST, appending a point to the message at each iteration and using the same id, so it modifies the previous one. For some reason that was only drawing the beginning of the line and then it stopped. The message seemed to be properly growing though. I didn't investigate much further.

  • POINTS, adding a new point each iteration, basically the same as for the spheres, but the points weren't showing up. I didn't investigate much more either.

content.raw:
Nice plotting tool.

I'm ignoring performance issues right now. Numerous visuals with the same geometry can be handled with instanced geometry in OGRE. Instanced geometry falls outside the scope of this work.

I think your 3d plotting may work better now. I get 60fps with line list. https://youtu.be/egWAMbU7f6Y
content.html:
Nice plotting tool.

I'm ignoring performance issues right now. Numerous visuals with the same geometry can be handled with instanced geometry in OGRE. Instanced geometry falls outside the scope of this work.

I think your 3d plotting may work better now. I get 60fps with line list. https://youtu.be/egWAMbU7f6Y

content.raw: The marker gets changed. The command line tool should allow markers to be changed.

content.raw:
I tried:

1. `gz marker -m 'action: ADD_MODIFY, type: POINTS, id: 2, point {x:1, y:1, z:0}, point {x:1, y:1, z:1}'` And 2 points appear.

1. Then I want to change that to a line and do `gz marker -m 'action: ADD_MODIFY, type: LINE_STRIP, id: 2, point {x:1, y:1, z:0}, point {x:1, y:1, z:1}'`. But nothing happens.

In fact, even if I just change the position of the points and keep the type the same, nothing seems to change. What am I doing wrong?
content.html:
I tried:

  1. gz marker -m 'action: ADD_MODIFY, type: POINTS, id: 2, point {x:1, y:1, z:0}, point {x:1, y:1, z:1}' And 2 points appear.

  2. Then I want to change that to a line and do gz marker -m 'action: ADD_MODIFY, type: LINE_STRIP, id: 2, point {x:1, y:1, z:0}, point {x:1, y:1, z:1}'. But nothing happens.

In fact, even if I just change the position of the points and keep the type the same, nothing seems to change. What am I doing wrong?

content.raw: Sounds like a bug. Checking.
content.html: Sounds like a bug. Checking.

content.raw: Just a note that this should never return null, except for the world visual. Every visual should have a parent, even if that parent is the world visual. There's a graph [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/1613/add-functions-to-get-a-visuals-ancestors/diff) which helps make sense of this.
content.html: Just a note that this should never return null, except for the world visual. Every visual should have a parent, even if that parent is the world visual. There's a graph here which helps make sense of this.

content.raw: We should always check pointers. An assumption about non-null can lead to seg faults.
content.html: We should always check pointers. An assumption about non-null can lead to seg faults.

content.raw: Oh sorry, that's not what I meant. I was just wondering if we want to add the parent field, even if the marker is attached directly to the world (as in, it doesn't really have a parent).
content.html: Oh sorry, that's not what I meant. I was just wondering if we want to add the parent field, even if the marker is attached directly to the world (as in, it doesn't really have a parent).

content.raw: Hmm. We could add an empty string, or leave the field out (which should also indicate there is no parent).
content.html: Hmm. We could add an empty string, or leave the field out (which should also indicate there is no parent).

content.raw:
This documentation feels out of place to me. It looks like it could go in the `MarkerManager`, but that class has been purposely excluded from the documentation. 

Who are we targeting this information at? This mentions tools which are out of the scope of the rendering library. Should this go into a tutorial instead?
content.html:
This documentation feels out of place to me. It looks like it could go in the MarkerManager, but that class has been purposely excluded from the documentation.

Who are we targeting this information at? This mentions tools which are out of the scope of the rendering library. Should this go into a tutorial instead?

content.raw:
This documentation goes into doxygen, and appears in the API documentation. Run `make doc` and take a look at the resulting documentation.

A tutorial is in the works, but it won't replace this information. More information is beneficial to users, and we have historically under performed when documenting the code.
content.html:
This documentation goes into doxygen, and appears in the API documentation. Run make doc and take a look at the resulting documentation.

A tutorial is in the works, but it won't replace this information. More information is beneficial to users, and we have historically under performed when documenting the code.

content.raw:
I'm not sure what's the difference between searching for things in this file or in `SearchForStuff`, pull request #2420 is adding a [check](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2420/get-plugin-info-with-ignition-transport/diff#Lcmake/SearchForStuff.cmakeF703T705) to `SearchForStuff` for ign-transport and that seemed to be enough. It also adds "found" messages so it's easy to find out which version was picked up.

In any case, if I only have ign-transport1, I get compile errors like these:

~~~
/home/louisep/code/gazeboA/gazebo/rendering/MarkerManager.cc: In member function ‘bool gazebo::rendering::MarkerManager::Init(gazebo::rendering::Scene*)’:
/home/louisep/code/gazeboA/gazebo/rendering/MarkerManager.cc:117:64: error: no matching function for call to ‘ignition::transport::Node::Advertise(const char [8], void (gazebo::rendering::MarkerManagerPrivate::*)(const ignition::msgs::Marker&), std::unique_ptr<gazebo::rendering::MarkerManagerPrivate>::pointer)’
         &MarkerManagerPrivate::OnMarkerMsg, this->dataPtr.get()))
~~~
content.html:
I'm not sure what's the difference between searching for things in this file or in SearchForStuff, pull request #2420 is adding a check to SearchForStuff for ign-transport and that seemed to be enough. It also adds "found" messages so it's easy to find out which version was picked up.

In any case, if I only have ign-transport1, I get compile errors like these:

/home/louisep/code/gazeboA/gazebo/rendering/MarkerManager.cc: In member function ‘bool gazebo::rendering::MarkerManager::Init(gazebo::rendering::Scene*)’:
/home/louisep/code/gazeboA/gazebo/rendering/MarkerManager.cc:117:64: error: no matching function for call to ‘ignition::transport::Node::Advertise(const char [8], void (gazebo::rendering::MarkerManagerPrivate::*)(const ignition::msgs::Marker&), std::unique_ptr<gazebo::rendering::MarkerManagerPrivate>::pointer)’
         &MarkerManagerPrivate::OnMarkerMsg, this->dataPtr.get()))

content.raw:
This file gets installed, and is used by others to compile code against gazebo. `SearchForStuff` is used internally by gazebo for compilation. Try commenting out lines 192-194 and then compile a program that uses gazebo and ignition-transport, such as the example included in this pull request.

I changed this pull request to require ign-transport2 or ign-transport3.
content.html:
This file gets installed, and is used by others to compile code against gazebo. SearchForStuff is used internally by gazebo for compilation. Try commenting out lines 192-194 and then compile a program that uses gazebo and ignition-transport, such as the example included in this pull request.

I changed this pull request to require ign-transport2 or ign-transport3.

content.raw: The API for publishing messages using `ignition-transport3` has changed and Gazebo is still not ready to use it. I think the bump to use Ignition-transport3 should include the appropriate changes to use the new API (probably accompanied by a 3.0.0 release to make Jenkins happy).
content.html: The API for publishing messages using ignition-transport3 has changed and Gazebo is still not ready to use it. I think the bump to use Ignition-transport3 should include the appropriate changes to use the new API (probably accompanied by a 3.0.0 release to make Jenkins happy).
